section_id: ## 1. The Stress-Energy Tensor from Walker Kinematics

hints.label: def-stress-energy-discrete
hints.title: Discrete Stress-Energy Tensor (N-Walker System)
hints.content:
176: :label: def-stress-energy-discrete
177: 
178: For a swarm of $N$ walkers with states $\mathcal{S}_t = \{(x_i(t), v_i(t), s_i(t))\}_{i=1}^N$ at time $t$, the **discrete stress-energy tensor** at spatial position $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is:
179: 
180: $$
181: T^{(N)}_{\mu\nu}(x, t) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N s_i(t) \, p^{(i)}_\mu(t) \, u^{(i)}_\nu(t) \, \delta(x - x_i(t))
182: 
183: $$
184: 
185: where:
186: 
187: **Four-momentum components** (in units where walker mass $m=1$):
188: 
189: $$
190: p^{(i)}_\mu =
191: \begin{cases}
192: \frac{1}{2}\|v_i\|^2 - \Phi(x_i) & \mu = 0 \text{ (energy)} \\
193: v_i^j & \mu = j \in \{1, \ldots, d\} \text{ (momentum)}
194: \end{cases}
195: 
196: $$
197: 
198: :::{note}
199: **Sign convention**: The fitness landscape $\Phi(x)$ represents where walkers are attracted (higher $\Phi$ = more attractive). In classical mechanics, potential energy $U$ satisfies $F = -\nabla U$, so attractive regions have LOW potential. Therefore, we define $U(x) = -\Phi(x)$, and the total energy is:
200: 
201: $$
202: E = \frac{1}{2}\|v\|^2 + U = \frac{1}{2}\|v\|^2 - \Phi
203: 
204: $$

hints.label: def-stress-energy-continuum
hints.title: Continuum Stress-Energy Tensor (Mean-Field Limit)
hints.content:
269: :label: def-stress-energy-continuum
270: 
271: Let $\mu_t(x, v) \, dx \, dv$ be the McKean-Vlasov measure from [05_mean_field.md](05_mean_field.md) satisfying:
272: 
273: $$
274: \partial_t \mu_t + v \cdot \nabla_x \mu_t + \nabla_v \cdot (F[\mu_t] \mu_t) = \frac{\gamma}{2} \Delta_v \mu_t + \frac{\sigma^2}{2}\Delta_v \mu_t
275: 
276: $$
277: 
278: where $F[\mu_t]$ is the mean-field force (adaptive force + viscous coupling + potential gradient).
279: 
280: The **continuum stress-energy tensor** is:
281: 
282: $$
283: T_{\mu\nu}(x, t) = \int_{\mathcal{V}} p_\mu(v) \, u_\nu(v) \, \mu_t(x, v) \, dv
284: 
285: $$
286: 
287: where:
288: 
289: **Four-momentum** (as function of velocity):
290: 
291: $$
292: p_\mu(v) =
293: \begin{cases}
294: \frac{1}{2}\|v\|^2 - \Phi(x) & \mu = 0 \\
295: v^j & \mu = j
296: \end{cases}
297: 
298: $$
299: 
300: (Note: Energy is kinetic + potential $U = -\Phi$, consistent with force $F = +\nabla\Phi$ toward high fitness)
301: 
302: **Four-velocity**:
303: 
304: $$
305: u_\nu(v) =
306: \begin{cases}
307: 1 & \nu = 0 \\
308: v^k/c & \nu = k
309: \end{cases}
310: 
311: $$

hints.section: ## 1. The Stress-Energy Tensor from Walker Kinematics
hints.raw_directive:
348: ### 1.4. Lorentz Covariance and Symmetry from Order-Invariance
349: 
350: :::{prf:theorem} Stress-Energy Tensor is Symmetric and Lorentz-Covariant
351: :label: thm-stress-energy-lorentz-covariant
352: 
353: The continuum stress-energy tensor $T_{\mu\nu}$ defined in {prf:ref}`def-stress-energy-continuum` satisfies:
354: 1. **Symmetry**: $T_{\mu\nu} = T_{\nu\mu}$
355: 2. **Lorentz covariance**: $T'_{\mu\nu}(x') = \Lambda^\alpha_\mu \Lambda^\beta_\nu T_{\alpha\beta}(x)$ under $\Lambda \in SO(1,3)$

hints.label: thm-order-invariance-lorentz-qft-cited
hints.title: Order-Invariant Functionals are Lorentz-Invariant (Reference)
hints.content:
386: :label: thm-order-invariance-lorentz-qft-cited
387: 
388: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be an order-invariant functional of a causal set $(E, \prec_{\text{CST}})$. In the continuum limit $N \to \infty$, if the causal set converges to a Lorentzian manifold $(M, g_{\mu\nu})$, then $\mathcal{F}$ becomes a **Lorentz-covariant** observable.

hints.title: Symmetry of Spatial Components
hints.content:
418: :label: lem-spatial-stress-symmetric
419: 
420: For any measure $\mu_t(x,v)$ solving the McKean-Vlasov equation, the spatial stress tensor is symmetric:
421: 
422: $$
423: T_{ij}[\mu_t] = T_{ji}[\mu_t] \quad \forall i,j \in \{1,\ldots,d\}
hints.section: ## 1. The Stress-Energy Tensor from Walker Kinematics
hints.raw_directive:
415: **Strategy**: We will show that the off-diagonal components $T_{0j} - T_{j0}$ vanish identically in the continuum limit by exploiting the structure of the McKean-Vlasov equation.
416: 
417: :::{prf:lemma} Symmetry of Spatial Components
418: :label: lem-spatial-stress-symmetric
419: 
420: For any measure $\mu_t(x,v)$ solving the McKean-Vlasov equation, the spatial stress tensor is symmetric:
421: 
422: $$
423: T_{ij}[\mu_t] = T_{ji}[\mu_t] \quad \forall i,j \in \{1,\ldots,d\}
424: $$

hints.label: lem-time-space-symmetry
hints.title: Time-Space Components Vanish via Flux Balance
hints.content:
437: :label: lem-time-space-symmetry
438: 
439: For any measure $\mu_t(x,v)$ solving the McKean-Vlasov equation with the structure from {prf:ref}`thm-mean-field-equation`:
440: 
441: $$
442: \partial_t \mu_t = L^\dagger \mu_t - c(z)\mu_t + B[\mu_t, m_d] + S[\mu_t]
443: $$
444:
hints.section: ## 1. The Stress-Energy Tensor from Walker Kinematics
hints.raw_directive:
434: Since multiplication is commutative, $v^i v^j = v^j v^i$, we immediately have $T_{ij} = T_{ji}$. $\square$
435: 
436: :::{prf:lemma} Time-Space Components Vanish via Flux Balance
437: :label: lem-time-space-symmetry
438: 
439: For any measure $\mu_t(x,v)$ solving the McKean-Vlasov equation with the structure from {prf:ref}`thm-mean-field-equation`:
440: 
441: $$
442: \partial_t \mu_t = L^\dagger \mu_t - c(z)\mu_t + B[\mu_t, m_d] + S[\mu_t]
443: $$
444: 
445: the off-diagonal time-space components satisfy a consistency condition that forces symmetry in the continuum limit.
